message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location of the burns on sun-exposed areas, fair skin, and lack of sunscreen suggest that the most likely cause is UV-B radiation. Infrared radiation and ionizing radiation are less likely causes. Child abuse should also be considered in cases of unexplained burns, but the history provided does not suggest this as a likely cause.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The severe burns on sun-exposed areas suggest sunburn, which is caused by UV-B radiation. Child abuse should always be considered in cases of suspicious bruising or burns, but there is no indication of abuse in this scenario. Infrared radiation and ionizing radiation are not typically associated with sunburns.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location and pattern of the burns suggest solar radiation as the cause, specifically UV-B radiation. Child abuse is a possibility but would have a different distribution of burns, while infrared and ionizing radiation are less likely causes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The burns on the sun-exposed areas of the skin indicate a condition called sunburn, which is caused by excessive exposure to UV-B radiation from the sun. The other options are less likely causes in this scenario, as child abuse or infrared radiation would normally result in burns in areas not directly exposed to the sun, and ionizing radiation is unlikely to be the cause in an otherwise healthy child.

Infrared radiation and ionizing radiation are not typically associated with sunburns. Child abuse would not be suspected without further evidence.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The severe burns on sun-exposed areas suggest that the child has been exposed to UV-B radiation for a prolonged period without protection. Infrared radiation and ionizing radiation do not typically cause burns on sun-exposed areas, and child abuse does not match the presentation or history given.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location and distribution of the burns, along with the fair skin and lack of sunscreen application, suggest that the most likely cause is UV-B radiation from the sun. Infrared radiation and ionizing radiation are less likely to cause burns on sun-exposed areas of the skin, and child abuse would have more random and widespread injury patterns.

Infrared radiation and ionizing radiation are unlikely causes. Child abuse should still be ruled out in any case of unexplained injuries.

Infrared radiation and ionizing radiation are not typically associated with sunburn. Child abuse would not be the most likely explanation in this scenario without further evidence or suspicion.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of severe burns on sun-exposed areas of the skin with fair skin and blond hair strongly suggest UV-B radiation as the most likely etiology. Infrared radiation and ionizing radiation are not typically associated with burns in this pattern. Child abuse may cause burns, but the parents deny any physical trauma or abuse.
